title: Do you believe a parallel Earth could exist? - Quora

Parallel Worlds, there are many of them. Sure, I believe in them and in past life regression we occasionally have clients who go into parallel reality instead of a past life. I am talking about ANOTHER YOU, who looks like you, has parents who look like your parents, but lives a different life - has a different occupation, has moved to another city or country, met a different mate etc. Are we seeing a different parallel world - or a variation of your current life when different choices were made? Dolores Cannon talks in one of her books and lectures about reality splitting into different timelines, every time we make a decision…Have you seen movie ‘Mr.Nobody” on Netflix? In this movie the character lives several parallel lives at the same time, as he is aware of each timeline when decisions were made…In future life progression we take clients into different versions of the future, and they can see how their life will shape when they make this or that choice. What are the reasons these parallel realities exist? There is ‘Many Worlds” theory explaining how it is possible from Quantum mechanics perspective Many-worlds interpretation - Wikipedia. There is also a theory that we live in a computer simulation, so every possible version of each game exist at the same time, like a code of a computer game, where every combination of every step is possible. We are actually living multiple parallel lives at the same time, like a simultaneous ‘Groundhog Day” playing every possible version of our current life, and after we die - all these multiple versions of you will unite into one Higher Self… Whatever the truth is - it is a mind blowing idea to meditate upon, and by accessing these parallel selves we can attract skills, and character traits we might want to have…you can find confident you, extrovertive you, a musician you, an artist you etc. These meditations can be quite useful, and you can take Burt Goldman class or get his CDs which promise to put you in touch with all these ‘parallel yous” - here is a short free meditation

Not as most people think of it. There is no reason for me to think that if there is a multiverse that those other universes have any real correlation with ours. I’d not expect to find parallel Earths if I could go to them unless the universes where infinite in size and have the same exact physics as our universe. But then if our universe was infinite we wouldn’t need to think about other universes to find another Earth as any finite volume within an infinite universe where the laws of nature are consistent will eventuate with duplicate regions of any finite volume since for any finite volume there are only a finite number of configurations is could have. Given what we know about our visible universe there would be no reason to think that a region like our solar system, galaxy, super cluster or even visible universe would be completely unique with an infinite universe. Answer to: Are you a strong believer of the parallel world theory? If yes, then why?

Q: Are you a strong believer of the parallel world theory? If yes, then why? A: Which one? There are between 4 and 9 different classes of parallel world hypotheses (not theories) – each with a lot of variants. Some are pretty much likely to be true, others are more out of this world. Many-worlds interpretation of quantum mechanics: the idea is that when a quantum event can happen, the idea is that all possible outcomes does happen. The regular Copenhagen interpretation is that these possible outcomes could be seen as a probability wave package of all superpositioned possible events, which collapses to one outcome when the event is observed. The many-worlds interpretation is that all outcomes happen, and each form a separate timeline of its own.Remember Schrödinger’s cat, a thought experiment where you put a cat in a box together with some means of killing it and a “quantum event trigger” – for instance a radioactive element which may or may not decay and send out radiation. In the Copenhagen interpretation, the cat would be dead and alive at the same time, until you open the box and observe the cat. Only then would you have a dead cat or a living cat.In the many-worlds interpretation, the timeline instead splits into two: one where the quantum event happened and the cat died, and one where it didn’t and the cat lives.Weirdly enough, there are some experimental support for both of these interpretations.Hubble volumes: The universe is big. Really big. And it probably doesn’t stop at the cosmic horizon of the visible universe, but continues beyond that. We just can’t see it, because there has not been enough time for light from beyond to reach us. Each such volume could be seen as a separate universe (called Hubble volume) since it cannot affect us anymore, and we cannot affect them.Hubble volumes almost certainly exist.And not only that: physicist Max Tegmark argues that there is a finite way that you can arrange particles in a finite volume, so within 101010155101010155metres, there ought to be a Hubble volume which is identical to ours with a copy of you. Somewhat closer, there may be a Hubble volume that is identical to ours, with the exception that you are of the other sex.String landscape: In string theory, you need a lot of extra dimensions (like height, width, depth dimensions, not alternate universe dimensions) – up to 11 is the most cited number, in which strings exist and vibrate. How they vibrate and thus form particles is not the thing here, but what to do with the other dimensions that we can’t see.String theory argues that most of those dimensions are compactified, so that only height-width-depth-time remains – the dimensions we are used to. The other 7 dimensions are folded in on themselves so tight that our particles misses them, and thus we can’t see or interact with those dimensions.Then, the hypothesis goes, there are many ways of compactifying the extra dimensions needed, each leading to their own set of space dimensions + time (presumably). Each of these possible ways could comprise its own universe.The idea is that all possible ways of folding dimensions exist as its own universe, or that random universe configurations pop up all the time like bubbles in the foam in the crown of a beer, and some of those may expand to a universe in which people can live.This is almost entirely hypothetical – the idea in itself seems sound, but is untestable at the moment.Eternal inflation: One idea in cosmology is that there is an eternal inflation going on. This is expanded from the Big Bang theory’s (not the TV show) idea of inflation, the very rapid expansion of space for the first 10−3210−32 seconds or thereabouts. Big Bang inflation is one possible explanation for the way that the Cosmic Microwave Background appears the way it do.The eternal inflation idea takes the Big Bang inflation, but makes it eternal and exponential instead. Then, the hypothesis argues that random quantum fluctuations in the inflation field leads to a volume within the eternal inflation field to slow down and become a universe of its own. This means that there is this expanding inflation field in which there are bubbles of universes.Although based on the Big Bang inflation theory, which has some support in cosmology, it goes way beyond it and is untestable at the moment. And it is completely hypothetical.Multiple simulations: There is this idea floating around that the universe is merely a simulation in an ancestor computer. In that case, what stops the ancestors from running several simulations? Each such simulation would then be its own universe, possibly with different natural laws depending on what parameters are programmed into the simulation. This would be a bit like running World of Warcraft and Minecraft at the same time.There is practically no support for this idea and is practically dismissed in cosmology, but it has some popularity among conspiracy theorists.

I do think that the possibility that alternate universes exist, and the reason is very simple: Differently from other idiotic ideologies (flat earth, no-vax, evolution denial and so forth) it not only does not harm anybody (so long as you don’t go around all day ranting and raving about it) but as far as I know, there hasn’t been any proof thanks to which we can say: “After concluding this research, we can claim without doubt that alternate universes exist” or even “After concluding this research, we can claim with reasonable certainty that Alternate Universes are not possible”. Mind you, my knowledge of physics is very limited so if there are any articles or journals which contradict my beliefs I would be grateful if you could point them out. That being said, I kind of like the idea that maybe there is another me in a different universe who right now is doing Bungee Jumping in his personal canyon.

Look at the two slit experiment that demonstrates wave/particle duality. A “particle” travels as a probability wave function until it needs to act as a particle for an observed interaction and the wave function collapses. All of the other wave probabilities still exist sideways in time in parallel timelines (worlds) that are not part of the observed/experienced one. This duality is also a part of our macro/physical experience. Think of yourself as a particle. Your future exists as a probability wave function. With each moment your consciousness causes the wave function to collapse as you observe/experience each physical moment. Here too, all of the other probabilities still exist sideways in time in parallel timelines/worlds. These are branching off all the time. In the bigger picture, through all of time parallels are being created. On a personal level most differences are only minor. But, looking at the universe as a whole, some parallel realities/worlds could be very different.

To be clear, I was a strong believer in the many-worlds interpretation, which is the pop sci term for the Everett Relative State interpretation of quantum mechanics from which the idea of parallel universes comes from outside of the cosmological model. I have conducted the first experiments that actual prove the ERSI and the work of Andrew Cleland and David Deutsch have contributed additional experimental support for the macroscopic ability of quantum superpositions the rigorous mathematical support of the ERSI as well. The only thing that kept physicists from taking ERSI seriously in many cases, was the presumed inability to prove it with physical experiments. Those days are over. In some way, I believe a Multiverse does exist, but I’m not certain how it would be structured. A Parallel Earth would mean that MWI Theory is correct and everything we do or don’t do really does create split realities where we did something different. Hubble Volumes are areas of space we can currently view but cannot see past because of the vast distance that light needs to travel. A theory states that past our Hubble Volume is a possibly infinite number of Volumes, some which could have their own physics. Inflation theory, that the universe is expanding, could cause portions of our universe to expand slower in certain areas, causing it to collapse into bubbles that are basically mini-verses. There are a few more theories, but these are some of the ones that are more popular. Personally, I believe in the Ultra-verse theory. The idea that an infinite number of universes, each one independent of the other, all exist at the same time in a region I would call “The Void”. Each universe is distinct and can have its own physical rules. Possibly each universe can form its own set of micro-verses from MWI or Inflation theory.

Do you believe in parallel worlds? Why? And why not? I’m a physicist. I hold op[inions based on evidence and understanding. I do not hold unevidenced opinions, which is a reasonable definition of belief. Parallel worlds are but vaguely defined, and are wholly unevidenced. I hold no beliefs, including in parallel worlds. I will form an opinion if and when evidence emerges. At this time its a fond imaginative unevidenced speculation of irrational dreamers. If it adds something to their lives to have dreams, so be it. but as science ?- its nonsense!

Yes but not from any spiritual or super natural perspective. If our universe is an expanding 4 dimensional hyper spherical shell then this suggests that there are most probably other concentric universes both outside and inside ours and that would make them parallel to ours. I don’t see this as a belief but having thought about the possible configurations of our universe long and hard I think this one is likely: morel likely than, for example, the infinite flat view of our universe which I believe (at lease almost believe) is as stupid as the idea of a flat Earth.

Some theories, like String Theory and Hawking’s theory of Eternal Inflation, posit such ideas as extra dimension, parallel universes, multiple universes, twin worlds of antimatter, etc. It is important to keep in mind that these findings are merely mathematical constructs with no manifestation whatsoever in reality. Such notions should be relegated to the realms of science-fiction and fantasy where they can be used as the basis for some great stories but should not be used as the basis for making decisions that affect your life.

Well, that depends on so many things.  By parallel Earth, are you thinking in the many-world's quantum mechanics way?  Because it seems a plausible way out of the measurement problem, but I'm not sure I would characterise those worlds as other universes. Of course even if QM is correct, it may not mean those many worlds are real. Lots of interpretations of quantum mechanics exist.  Do you mean it in the whole multiverse way? Well IF it exists and IF there are an infinite number of them, then I guess it must do. However that is a few IFs....  Do I believe in it? No, do I believe its not impossible given what we know, well yeah. But it is quite a jump and at best I think it is uncertain so far. You've also got to define existence as at the minute, all that exists must be in this universe. I think philosophy and physics have a way to go on this one.

No. I believe a multiverse can exist, but the other universes will be different from ours, just as galaxies are different from one another. Probably their physical laws have different parameters, at least in the string theory view. However with the vast numbers of stars, planets and galaxies there are sure to be many planets that are similar to earth in terms of their environment. And  they will give rise to life and potentially intelligent life that may in some aspects be similar to human life.

I believe all kinds of things, depending on my mood. There's some theoretical basis for parallel universes but,  so far,  no hard evidence. A huge or infinite number of parallel universes would open up the possibility of a planet or planets similar to Earth. It's all speculative.

I don’t believe reality gives a rat’s ass what we believe. And, whatever may be outside perceptual reality, we may never know if it exist or is relevant. In other words, why should I give a shit if we exist in parallel worlds? Why would I care if have a 1000 other penises and a 1000 other girlfriends to play with them? All I can experience is the here and now. And, if I start experiencing something else, it probably means that I am bugfuck crazy, not entering some extra-perceptual reality.

Not just parallel Earths, but parallel galaxies, universes, timelines...  Quantum mechanics predicts the existence of parallel universes.  We should take Everett's many worlds interpretation of quantum mechanics - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Many-worlds_interpretation - seriously because: Everett's is a simpler theory, since it does not require the wavefunction collapse postulate; by Okham's razor Everett is therefore preferred.Everett's theory is better defined, since a definition of observers and measurement is not required.  Such a requirement in the Cophengan interpretation is somewhat akin to magic.Everett's theory is deterministic.

Do you believe in parallel worlds? If so, why? “Parallel world” requires a fourth spatial dimension. One dimension is a line. Blood can escape by flowing into the second dimension.Two dimensions define a plane. Blood can escape by flowing up or down into the third dimension.In three dimensions you can have arteries. Blood can escape by flowing into the fourth dimension.That does not happen, so the concept is disproved.

Q: Are you a strong believer of the parallel world theory? If yes, then why? THE MANY WORLDS HYPOTHESIS? YES! Aside from the infinite (or near infinite) worlds, it is the most parsimonious interpretation because it has the fewest ad hoc assumptions. The wave function never collapses in the Schrödinger equation and it never collapses in MWI. The measurement problem is resolved. Locality is restored. Einstein's dream of a clockwork universe (multiverse) is revived. MWI is completely deterministic, every event has a cause. This satisfies not only Einstein's intuition that God does not play dice, but lots of other physicists' intuition too. Of course intuition is not science, and neither is MWI.

The only parallel world is heaven or Hell. The Word of God says “after death the Judgment.” This should not cause any concern when you realise that Jesus, the son of God died for your sins, and if you receive Him you will go to Heaven when you die. The Bible says, “as many as received Him, to them gave power to become sons of God.” You can be sure of being welcomed if you accept Christ.

There is no way to answer the question except to say that, while a staple of science fiction stories, movies, comic books, television programs, computer websites and (probably) computer games, we have no scientific (or other) evidence to suggest there are parallel earths or universes. One can come up with a good mathematical description, but that does not constitute either evidence or proof. We could as easily come up with a mathematical description of a 3-km (1.8-mile) high super tree, but they still wouldn’t exist.
